title: Numerical Expressions
description: Test your knowledge of number formatting, SI/metric units, and conversion calculations.

questions.stem: How should numbers at the beginning of sentences be written?
questions.rationale: Numbers beginning sentences must always be spelled out, regardless of size.

questions.stem: Find the error in this sentence:
questions.text: 25 participants attended the training session on budget planning.

errors.reason: Numbers at sentence beginning must be spelled out

questions.rationale: Numbers beginning sentences must be spelled out: 'Twenty-five participants...'

questions.stem: What should you do with very large numbers at sentence beginning?
questions.rationale: Very large numbers create awkward spelling, so rewrite sentences to avoid them at the beginning.

questions.stem: Complete this sentence correctly: ________ thousand applications were received this year.
questions.rationale: Numbers at sentence beginning must be spelled out: 'Three thousand applications...'

questions.stem: Which sentence is better?

options.label: Two thousand four hundred fifty-seven people applied.
There were two thousand four hundred fifty-seven applicants.

questions.rationale: Rewriting avoids awkward spelled-out large numbers while maintaining clarity.

questions.stem: How should even dollar amounts be written in text?
questions.rationale: Even dollar amounts don't need decimal places in running text: '$5' not '$5.00'

questions.stem: Find the formatting error:

errors.reason: Need space between number and unit, and units don't take plural 's'

questions.rationale: SI units require space between number and unit, and don't use plural forms.

questions.stem: The budget allocates $________ million for the new facility.
questions.rationale: Use numerals with currency symbols and express millions clearly: '$2.5 million'

questions.stem: How should measurements always be written?

options.label: With numerals, regardless of the basic number rules

questions.rationale: Measurements always use numerals, even for numbers under 10: '5 km' not 'five kilometres'

questions.stem: Which is the correct format for Canadian government documents?
questions.rationale: Temperature uses degree symbol directly attached to C: '25°C'

questions.stem: What is the preferred date format for Canadian government documents?
questions.rationale: Canadian standard format is 'January 15, 2024' or ISO format 'YYYY-MM-DD'

questions.stem: Find the formatting error:
questions.text: The meeting is scheduled for 3/15/24 at 2:30 PM.

errors.reason: Use full date format, not American MM/DD/YY style

questions.rationale: Use full Canadian date format and 24-hour time for government documents.

questions.stem: In ISO format, January 15, 2024 would be written as ________.
questions.rationale: ISO date format is YYYY-MM-DD: '2024-01-15'

questions.stem: When should you include time zones in documents?

options.label: For meetings or deadlines involving multiple locations

questions.rationale: Always specify time zones when readers might be in different time zones.

questions.stem: What time format is preferred for formal government documents?
questions.rationale: 24-hour clock (14:30) is preferred for formal documents to avoid AM/PM confusion.

questions.stem: How should percentages be written in formal prose?
questions.rationale: In formal prose, spell out 'percent' and use numerals: '15 percent'

questions.stem: The response rate improved by ________ over the previous year.
questions.rationale: Use numerals with spelled-out 'percent' in formal writing.

questions.stem: When is the % symbol appropriate?
questions.rationale: The % symbol is appropriate in tables, charts, and technical documents.

questions.stem: Find the error in this statistical report:

errors.reason: Should specify confidence level (usually 95%) and use standard CI abbreviation

questions.rationale: Always specify the confidence level and use standard abbreviation 'CI'.

questions.stem: What should always be reported with statistical findings?

options.label: Sample size (n) and confidence intervals when relevant

questions.rationale: Statistical reports should include sample size and confidence intervals for transparency.

questions.stem: Which of these is NOT a base SI unit?
questions.rationale: Litre is a derived unit. The seven base SI units are: metre, kilogram, second, ampere, kelvin, mole, candela.

questions.stem: The prefix 'kilo' represents a factor of ________.
questions.rationale: 'Kilo' means 1000 or 10³: 1 km = 1000 m

questions.stem: How should SI unit symbols be written?

options.label: Never with plurals, lowercase unless derived from proper names

questions.rationale: SI symbols never take plurals and are lowercase unless derived from proper names (like W for watt from Watt).

questions.stem: Match the SI unit with its symbol:
questions.rationale: Learn the symbols for common derived SI units used in government documents.

questions.stem: Find the SI formatting error:
questions.text: The pressure reading was 145kPa at a temperature of 25° C.

errors.reason: Need space between number and unit
No space between degree symbol and C

questions.rationale: SI units need space between number and unit, but temperature symbols attach directly.

questions.stem: To convert inches to centimetres, multiply by:
questions.rationale: 1 inch = 2.54 centimetres exactly (defined conversion factor).

questions.stem: 60 miles equals approximately ________ kilometres.
questions.rationale: 60 miles × 1.609 = 96.54 km (round appropriately for context)

questions.stem: What is 20°C in Fahrenheit?
To convert pounds to kilograms, multiply by:
questions.rationale: 1 pound = 0.454 kilograms (1 kg = 2.205 pounds is the reverse)

questions.stem: A room measures 12 feet by 15 feet. What is its area in square metres?
steps: Convert feet to metres: 12 ft × 0.3048 = 3.66 m
Convert feet to metres: 15 ft × 0.3048 = 4.57 m
questions.rationale: Convert each dimension then multiply, or convert the area directly using 0.093 m²/ft².

questions.stem: When should scientific notation be used?

options.label: For all numbers in scientific documents
For very large or very small numbers

questions.rationale: Scientific notation is appropriate for very large (>10,000) or very small (<0.001) numbers.

questions.stem: In legal documents, the fine amount should be written as: The fine shall not exceed ________ thousand dollars ($_______).
questions.rationale: Legal documents use both written and numerical forms for clarity and legal precision.

questions.stem: What should statistical reports always include?

options.label: Sample size, confidence intervals, and significance levels

questions.rationale: Complete statistical reporting includes sample size (n), confidence intervals, and significance testing results.

questions.stem: Find the error in this scientific notation:
questions.text: The distance to the moon is approximately 384,000 km or 3.84 × 10⁵ m.
questions.rationale: Convert units carefully: 384,000 km = 384,000,000 m = 3.84 × 10⁸ m

questions.stem: How should number ranges be expressed?

options.label: Consistently within document, either 'to' or hyphen

questions.rationale: Choose either 'to' or hyphen/en dash for ranges and use consistently throughout the document.
